newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Independent analyst sees coffee production rise.
newsitem.headline: Independent analyst sees coffee production rise.

text.p: High international coffee prices could help revive Colombia's beleaguered coffee industry and boost production to 13.5 million 60-kg bags in the coming years, a private analyst said Tuesday.

Colombia's coffee output has dropped to an average of about 12 million bags per year since the end of the International Coffee Organization quota agreement between producers and consumers in 1989 and the fall in international prices.

But world prices for the bean have risen on forecasts of a lower than normal harvest in Brazil and a 10.4 million 60-kg bag crop in Colombia in the 1996/97 year, compared to 12.9 million bags last year.

"Given current prices there will be a recovery in coffee production to 13.5 million bags which would be a desirable level of output," said Mauricio Cardenas, head of the independent think-tank Fedesarrollo and son of the National Coffee Growers' Federation chief.
He did not say how long it would take for Colombia's average annual coffee crop to rise to that figure.

Cardenas said higher coffee prices would boost the overall growth of Colombia's Gross Domestic product in 1997, which he said would be close to four percent this year compared to GDP growth of less than three percent last year.
